posts.cooked:
Hey, I have a quick question. I am trying to run a command in parallel with a path following command. In my AutoIntakeNote command, i’m using an optical sensor to detect if a note has been picked up, and when it has, I’m telling the collector to retract back in and feed the note to our pivoting shooter. The problem is that if I place the note way closer to the robot (way before the path finishes), it seems that the path following the command ends instantly.

However, the command scheduler does indeed schedule the command i’m passing in, and note is still fed to the shooter as expected, i just want the path following command to not be interrupted as well. I suspect the .schedule() method is canceling all other current commands, even though it says, " Does nothing for commands already scheduled." Any ideas on how to fix this?

Execute method of my AutoIntakeNoteCmd:

image 942×446 21.5 KB image 1350×392 38.8 KB

image 942×446 21.5 KB

image 942×446 21.5 KB

image 1350×392 38.8 KB

image 1350×392 38.8 KB

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked:
mjjain:

I suspect the .schedule() method is canceling all other current commands, even though it says, " Does nothing for commands already scheduled."

It will cancel all commands which use overlapping subsystems to the command being scheduled.  This is a core tenet of the command framework (you can’t have two commands that require the same subsystem running at the same time).

That makes sense, but the interesting thing is that I removed the addRequirements line in the constructor of my command as a sanity check, and the same thing still happened. Even with it uncommented, the command only requires the shooter and collector subsystems and not the drivetrain. The follow path command only requires the drivetrain, so there don’t seem to be any conflicting subsystem requirements unless I’m missing something.

Pretty sure this is what pathplanner is doing:

And in my SwerveBase AutoBuilder code:

I’m passing the SwerveBase as a requirement with the this keyword.

So I can see what you were saying about how the .schedule() method handles requirement conflicts, but the subsystem requirements shouldn’t conflict because the drivetrain is never added as a requirement in the AutoIntakeNoteCmd, and the collector and shooter are never accessed in AutoBuilder.

Is there a different way to do this or am I making a silly mistake somewhere?
Do you have any ideas based on my reply ? Any help is appreciated, thank you again!

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
So my quick readthrough of your logic is you want:

Start intake

Run Intake until you detect note

In parallel, tilt collector and shooter toward each other

Wait a bit

Index note and shoot

Psuedo code-ish:

Or something like that.
Yeah, that seems to basically be what I’m doing, but how do I make it not end the path following command?

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
You are basically doing that…but not doing that.  What I’m suggesting, is the way you’ve contructed things is unnecessary, and there’s likely a cleaner way to do it.

If you composed and scheduled your intake command the way that I wrote it, you’d have no need to be calling .schedule() on anything, if indeed that is the root of the issue.

If your hope is to complete the sequence in the five steps I enumerated, there’s no need to shedule a new command at all.  You just need to build your command sequence similar to what I’ve done and it will work.

If for some reason you think you need to schedule a command at runtime, or you need to fork off a set of commands from your current command group (thus having a separate set of requirements etc) then you probably will need a DeferredCommand or a ProxyCommand in your current setup.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Nothing about the code you shared seems to be requiring your drivetrain (or whatever you called it) subsystem, so i dont see any reason the path following command should be cancelled.  The caveat to that statement would be if the pathfollowing command requires one of the commands this does use.  Without seeing all of your code, we can only guess.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
NewtonCrosby:

you’d have no need to be calling .schedule() on anything, if indeed that is the root of the issue.

I doubt this is the root of the issue, but yeah you shouldn’t ever call schedule manually.  You should bind commands to events or compose them only.

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
Fletch1373:

Nothing about the code you shared seems to be requiring your drivetrain (or whatever you called it) subsystem, so i dont see any reason the path following command should be cancelled.  …

My guess is that the scheduling of the new command, requires a subsystem that is in the parallelcommandgroup where the path following is happening.  When the schedule happens, the other commands with those subsystems are cancelled, to include the group running the path (since requirements of the group are an amalgam of all the individual command requirements).

Maybe.
Yeah exactly, I understand that the way I’m doing things rn is suboptimal but I don’t see why it shouldn’t work lol

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: No one can help you in more detail if you don’t share all of your code.  A github link is best.

posts.cooked: Sorry about that, here you go!

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: Your command cancels itself when it schedules another command that requires the same subsystems it does.  You are probably inheriting the requirement in the drive command through command group semantics.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.cooked: I see, how exactly would I go about fixing this?

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Don’t ever call .schedule manually, and instead use composition or triggers so that it’s always obvious how transitions between commands occur.

Use onInterrupt and print statements to track down where the interrupt is occuring, and proceed from there.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: NewtonCrosby
posts.cooked:
mjjain:

I see, how exactly would I go about fixing this?

Compose your command sequence so you won’t be scheduling instances of commands that require the same subsystems as the groups running your paths.

Here’s a good reference with visuals on commands and their lifecycles .  Then you can look at the various composition methods from wpilib .

If you’ve got those down, try to reimplement your AutoIntakeNoteCmd to look similar to the one I already put above…and you’ll be pretty close.

link_counts.title: Command Compositions — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked: Okay, yeah, this ended up working! You were right about the .schedule() method canceling other commands somewhere in the CommandScheudler implementation. Thanks again to everyone who helped!

data.fancy_title: CommandScheduler.getInstance().schedule() seems to be cancelling with path following command in parallel?
data.title: CommandScheduler.getInstance().schedule() seems to be cancelling with path following command in parallel?

accepted_answer.excerpt:
Don’t ever call .schedule manually, and instead use composition or triggers so that it’s always obvious how transitions between commands occur.
Use onInterrupt and print statements to track down where the interrupt is occuring, and proceed from there.
